bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emilie M.] Reed and Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 16, 1944

div1.p: Hench is thankful for the letters and photographs loaned to him by Reed and asks for identification of Walter Reed in a photograph.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Blossom [Emile M.] Reed and Emilie Lawrence Reed, December 16, 1944
div1.opener:
Mrs. Walter Reed
and
Mrs. Blossom Reed
Blue Ridge Summit,
Pennsylvania
My dear Ladies:
div1.p: Please permit me to send you my sincerest Christmas wishes.

When I visited you last year, you had run out of the Walter
Reed stamps and regretted that you did not have more. You may remember
that my mother, 79 years old, has gotten considerable pleasure in recent
years in collecting American stamps. Thinking that you might like to
have some more of the Walter Reed stamps, she and I have been collecting
a few, which we send you with our best wishes. I must, regretfully, in-
form you that about a week ago mother became seriously ill and is now in
a critical condition. In all likelihood, I will leave here tomorrow to
go to Rochester to be with her.

I enclose a picture of my little boy. Don't you admit that he
is very cute and very sturdy? I have only seen him about three times in
his life and it is very distressing to me to be away from my family so
much. As the wife and mother [unclear] of a soldier, you know exactly
what that means.

When I visited you, you were very kind to lend me a collection
of letters and photographs of Major Reed. I have been studying them very
carefully in the limited time at my disposal. I have guarded them very
carefully and at the times when I have left town. I have placed them in
a safety deposit box of the bank vault. One of the photographs which you
loaned me, I had copied in order to send copies to some of the yellow
fever survivors, in the hope that we might identify them more clearly in
the photograph. General Truby seems to think that Major Reed may be the
figure in the back row, second from the right. He is not in uniform; he
has on a derby hat, dark coat and vest, and white pants. I enclose a copy
of General Truby's letter and would be most grateful if you would tell me
if Major Reed is this figure. I don't expect to be home more than a
couple of weeks. My home address is 517 Fourth Street, S. W., Rochester,
Minnesota, but I have no doubt that in your Christmas rush, you would
probably prefer to write me here after I return.

PSH/cb
16 December 1944
Sheet Two
To: Mrs. Walter Reed,
and Mrs. Blossom Reed

I am always delighted to hear from you at any time. Please
accept my sincere wishes for a very happy Christmas.
div1.closer: Gratefully yours, PHILIP S. HENCH, Lt. Col., M.C. Chief of the Medical Service
